Article Title: Reliance is bringing back Shein products in India; but with a Big Desi twist
Article Text:
Reliance Ihas poured more than $2 billion into its retailing unit over the past year

Condition for Reliance and Shein to sell products in India

Shein app ban in 2020

Shein 's return to India is conditional on strict data-related requirements. Commerce minister Piyush Goyal has revealed that the Chinese fast-fashion retailer have to meet stringent data localisation conditions to re-enter the Indian market after its 2020 ban. These conditions include relinquishing control of its local operations and data to its Indian partner, Reliance Retail, ensuring that all data remains within India and both parties adhere to strict security measures.In a parliamentary response, Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal outlined the terms of the agreement between Reliance Retail and Shein, a report by news agency PTI said.Goyal highlighted Reliance Retail Ventures Ltd's (RRVL) partnership with Shein, stating that its subsidiary, Reliance Retail Ltd (RRL), has a technology agreement with Roadget Business Pte Ltd, the Singapore-based owner of Shein.Shein will operate solely as a technology provider, while Reliance Retail maintains full ownership and control of the platform, including all data collected from Indian customers.‚ÄúThe licence agreement covered the protection that ownership and control of the platform will always remain with RRVL through its wholly-owned subsidiary,‚Äù said Goyal in the reply.He added that ‚Äúas per the agreement, at all times, the platform will be hosted on infrastructure in India and all platform data will remain in India with Shein having no access to, or rights over, such data.‚ÄùThe agreement requires consenting parties to follow Indian laws and ensure localisation of infrastructure and platform data.‚ÄúRRVL is also advised to ensure compliance with all existing laws of India and security audit of complete infrastructure can be undertaken by any government empanelled cyber security auditor,‚Äù he said.Under this agreement, the new platform will create a network of local manufacturers and suppliers who will manufacture products under the brand Shein and sell them domestically and globally.‚ÄúIt is expected that this will help in the growth of the Indian textiles manufacturing sector , including local handicraft and create significant employment,‚Äù said Goyal.The minister also clarified that the ‚Äúsale of Shein-branded products in India was not banned,‚Äù but the app was.Shein was among the group of Chinese apps that the government banned in 2020, based on concerns about national security and data privacy. Shein's re-entry involved extensive scrutiny from multiple government agencies, including the Ministry of Textiles, the IT Ministry, and the Ministry of Home Affairs.Shein products were available in the online market through platforms as Amazon.
Article Summary: Shein's return to India is conditional on strict data-related requirements. Shein must relinquish control of its local operations and data to its Indian partner, Reliance Retail. All data must remain within India and both parties adhere to strict security measures.

Article Title: Paypal founder Peter Thiel: Silicon Valley called staff back to office as they realised that employees weren‚Äôt actually working
Article Text:
Peter Thiel

Employees working remotely weren't actually working

Companies have offered various reasons for pushing employees back into offices, but Paypal founder Peter Thiel provides a starkly blunt explanation for the corporate shift away from remote work. He argues that Silicon Valley discovered a significant portion of remote workers weren't actually productive. Peter Thiel is a close friend of Tesla CEO Elon Musk.Thiel is also part of the famous Paypal Mafia. The term Paypal Mafia was coined in a 2007 Fortune cover story, which examined the outsize influence within the tech scene of a group of men who had launched a payments startup called PayPal almost a decade earlier. When PayPal was acquired by eBay for $1.5 billion in 2002, these newly capitalised techies dispersed like seeds to germinate new tech companies. The names include Tesla, LinkedIn, Palantir Technologies, SpaceX, Slide, YouTube , Yelp, and Yammer.In a TV interview recently, Thiel contrasted the current situation with the pre-pandemic era, citing a statistic that around 94% of U.S. federal government workers were working from home. He then asserted that Silicon Valley's experience with remote work over one or two years revealed its ineffectiveness. "When people didn‚Äôt come into the office, they weren‚Äôt working," Thiel stated. He described the initial period as one where worker power allowed them to "insist on not working." However, he continued, after two years, companies "fired a bunch of these people and reasserted control because you realize, wow, there were all these people we hired and they‚Äôre not working. And it doesn‚Äôt matter, and we can just get rid of them."Thiel's comments resonate with the wave of tech layoffs that occurred in late 2022 and early 2023, impacting tens of thousands of employees at major companies like Google , Meta, and Amazon . These layoffs coincided with the waning of the COVID-19 pandemic. Thiel's perspective suggests a correlation between remote work, perceived low productivity, and these mass layoffs. He implies that tech companies realized the dispensability of many remote workers, leading to their dismissal with minimal impact on business operations.This aligns with observations that the large-scale layoffs had little discernible effect on the performance of these tech giants. Amazon announced the official end of remote work for all employees starting in 2025 (though some flexibility remains for certain roles and teams). Meta and Google have also been actively encouraging employees to return to physical offices, implementing policies like requiring a certain number of in-office days per week. This shift by major tech players signals a potential decline in the prevalence of remote work as the pandemic becomes a more distant memory. Some sources suggest that the return-to-office push is also linked to concerns about maintaining company culture, fostering innovation through in-person collaboration, and managing performance more effectively. Additionally, commercial real estate interests and the desire to revitalize urban centers may be contributing factors.
Article Summary: Paypal founder Peter Thiel argues that Silicon Valley discovered a significant portion of remote workers weren't actually productive. Thiel's comments resonate with the wave of tech layoffs that occurred in late 2022 and early 2023, impacting tens of thousands of employees at major companies like Google and Amazon.

Article Title: How Nigerian scammers used WhatsApp, Instagram in international romance and crypto scam
Article Text:
Representative image

How scammers targeted their victims

Nigerian authorities have busted a major international scam operation that lured victims with promises of romance and lucrative cryptocurrency investments, a report has said. In a raid on a seven-story building in Lagos, the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) arrested 792 suspects, including 148 Chinese nationals and 40 Filipinos.According to a report by news agency Reuters, these suspects were detained on December 10. It added that the building housed a sophisticated call centre where scammers targeted victims primarily from the Americas and Europe.The operation involved a network of Nigerian and foreign nationals working in tandem. Nigerian accomplices used to initiate contact with potential victims online, building trust and establishing relationships, the report said.The report also highlighted that scammers used instant messaging app like WhatsApp , and social media platforms Instagram to target people. They employed a combination of romance scams and fraudulent investment schemes to defraud unsuspecting individuals.‚ÄúNigerian accomplices were recruited by the foreign kingpins to prospect for victims online through phishing, targeting mostly Americans, Canadians, Mexicans and several others from European countries,‚Äù said EFCC spokesperson Wilson Uwujaren.Once victims were hooked, foreign operatives would take over, pressuring them to invest in bogus cryptocurrency schemes and other non-existent projects.‚ÄúThe Nigerians would win the confidence of the victims, and then the foreigners would take over the actual task of defrauding them,‚Äù explained EFCC spokesperson Wilson Uwujaren.The EFCC seized computers, phones, and vehicles during the raid and is collaborating with international partners to investigate potential links to organised crime.
Article Summary: The Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) arrested 792 suspects, including 148 Chinese nationals and 40 Filipinos. The operation involved a network of Nigerian and foreign nationals working in tandem. Nigerian accomplices used to initiate contact with potential victims online, building trust and establishing relationships.

Article Title: New York to London in 1 hour? Elon Musk proposes $20 billion tunnel plan
Article Text:
Elon Musk proposes New York-London tunnel for $20 billion

The role of Hyperloop technology

Challenges facing the project

Technical feasibility: Building a 3,000-mile tunnel under the Atlantic Ocean would require overcoming immense engineering hurdles. Factors such as oceanic pressure, underwater geography, and environmental concerns pose significant risks. Any construction would need to withstand harsh underwater conditions and potential seismic activity.

Cost and funding: Even with Musk‚Äôs $20 billion estimate, securing funding for such a project would be challenging. Public-private partnerships, international cooperation, and large-scale investments would be essential to finance the tunnel‚Äôs development.

Technological readiness: While Hyperloop technology shows promise, it remains largely unproven on the scale required for a transatlantic tunnel. Ensuring safety, reliability, and efficiency at such high speeds is a considerable challenge.

Environmental impact: The environmental effects of constructing a tunnel beneath the Atlantic Ocean must be carefully studied. Disruptions to marine ecosystems, carbon emissions from construction, and long-term maintenance concerns require thorough analysis.

Regulatory and geopolitical issues: Coordinating a project of this magnitude between multiple governments, agencies, and stakeholders across two continents adds another layer of complexity. Regulatory approval, legal frameworks, and international agreements would need to be established.

Public and industry reactions

The ambitious idea of a transatlantic tunnel connecting New York City and London has resurfaced, sparked by Elon Musk ‚Äôs latest statement claiming that his company, The Boring Company, could construct it for $20 billion. The concept, which has been discussed for decades, involves building a massive tunnel under the Atlantic Ocean spanning over 3,000 miles (4,800 kilometers). Historically, such a project has been viewed as impractical due to its enormous cost, technical challenges, and the engineering scale required. However, Musk‚Äôs innovative approach and advancements in technology have reignited global interest in this unprecedented infrastructure project.The idea of a transatlantic tunnel is not new and has long been a subject of fascination among engineers and futurists. Proposed designs typically envision a tunnel stretching beneath the Atlantic Ocean, facilitating high-speed rail travel between the United States and the United Kingdom. If realized, it would significantly transform global travel and logistics. Currently, a flight between London and New York takes approximately eight hours. A transatlantic tunnel, theoretically capable of reducing this travel time to under an hour, would be a revolutionary step in human transportation.Previous estimates placed the cost of such a project at an astronomical $19.8 trillion (equivalent to 15.5 trillion British pounds). By comparison, constructing the Channel Tunnel‚Äîa 38-kilometer underwater tunnel linking England and France‚Äîtook six years and cost $12 billion. The scale of a transatlantic tunnel would be magnitudes larger, presenting both financial and engineering hurdles that many consider insurmountable.Elon Musk, the CEO of Tesla, SpaceX, and The Boring Company, has a reputation for proposing bold and transformative projects. During recent discussions, Musk claimed that his tunneling venture, The Boring Company, could complete the transatlantic tunnel for just $20 billion. This assertion has drawn significant attention, as it is a mere fraction of previous estimates. Musk‚Äôs confidence stems from advancements in tunneling technology and his pioneering Hyperloop concept, which could revolutionize the way people travel across long distances.According to Musk, the cost reduction would be achieved through innovative tunneling techniques, automation, and scalability. The Boring Company has already demonstrated its ability to construct tunnels efficiently and at lower costs in smaller projects, such as the Las Vegas Convention Center Loop. However, the sheer magnitude of a transatlantic tunnel poses unprecedented challenges that extend beyond existing projects.Central to Musk‚Äôs proposal is the integration of Hyperloop technology, a concept he introduced in 2013. Hyperloop involves pressurized vehicles traveling through vacuum-sealed tunnels, eliminating air resistance and enabling speeds far beyond traditional trains. In theory, Hyperloop trains could reach speeds of over 3,000 miles per hour (4,800 kilometers per hour), reducing the travel time between London and New York to just one hour.The technology relies on maintaining a near-vacuum environment inside the tunnel, allowing vehicles to glide with minimal friction. Hyperloop pods would be propelled using magnetic levitation (maglev) technology, already employed in high-speed trains in countries like Japan and China. While still in the experimental stage, significant advancements have been made in recent years to bring Hyperloop closer to reality. Musk‚Äôs proposal combines this futuristic transportation model with innovative tunneling solutions, positioning it as a feasible option for intercontinental travel.Despite Musk‚Äôs optimism, the transatlantic tunnel faces several critical challenges that cannot be overlooked:Musk‚Äôs proposal has garnered mixed reactions from experts, policymakers, and the public. Proponents argue that the transatlantic tunnel, if realized, would be a game-changer for global connectivity, commerce, and travel. It could significantly reduce travel times, boost trade, and create millions of jobs during construction and operation.Critics, however, remain skeptical. They point to the ambitious timeline, the unproven nature of Hyperloop technology, and the history of cost overruns in large infrastructure projects. Many question whether Musk‚Äôs $20 billion estimate is realistic, given the unprecedented scale of the tunnel.Nevertheless, Musk‚Äôs track record of delivering groundbreaking innovations‚Äîsuch as reusable rockets with SpaceX and electric vehicles with Tesla‚Äîhas led some to believe that his vision, though audacious, is worth exploring.
Article Summary: Elon Musk claims his tunneling venture, The Boring Company, could complete a 3,000-mile tunnel between New York and London for $20 billion. Such a project has been viewed as impractical due to its enormous cost, technical challenges, and the engineering scale required. Central to Musk‚Äôs proposal is the integration of Hyperloop technology, a concept he introduced in 2013.

What is digital arrest scam



How to identify a digital arrest scam

Unexpected Contact from ‚ÄòOfficials‚Äô: Be cautious if someone claims to be from government agencies like the police, CBI, income tax officers, or customs agents, contacts you. Be cautious especially if they claim urgent legal action is being initiated or warranted. They might allege that you or one of your family members is involved in a serious crime like money laundering, tax evasion, or drug trafficking.

Fear-based language and urgency: Scammers may request video calls, disguising themselves in police uniforms, using government logos, or creating official-sounding background noise to appear legitimate. They often threaten arrest or immediate legal action, demanding a quick response and using legal terms to sound convincing. In some cases, they create a police station-like set up to further convince victims of their credibility.

Request for sensitive information or payment: Scammers may ask for personal information or demand large sums of money, promising that this will clear up your involvement in the alleged crime. They may also coerce you to transfer money to their account until the investigation is complete. Terms like ‚Äúclearing your name‚Äù, ‚Äúassisting with the investigation‚Äù, or ‚Äúrefundable security deposit/escrow account‚Äù might be used by them to persuade you into transferring money to specified bank accounts or UPI IDs.

Tips to stay safe

Pause and Verify: If you receive unexpected calls or messages about legal issues, take a moment to verify. Stay calm, as scammers rely on fear and urgency. Real government and law enforcement agencies will never ask for money or investigate cases through phone or video calls. Always confirm the caller‚Äôs identity and consult trusted sources before taking any action.

Use Support Channels: Report suspicious numbers to the national cybercrime helpline by dialing 1930 or the Department of Telecommunication (https://sancharsaathi.gov.in/sfc/).

Article Title: Airbnb blocked 74,000 bookings worldwide on New Year eve in 2023, and says will follow same measures in 2024 as well
Article Text:
How Airbnb checks ‚Äòparty‚Äô booking

Planning a New Year's Eve party at an Airbnb? Think again. The company is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. This technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location. While implemented worldwide, the technology will specifically target the US, UK, Australia, Canada, France, Puerto Rico, Spain and New Zealand. Last New Year's Eve, Airbnb blocked 74,000 such bookings.High-risk bookings will be blocked or redirected to alternative accommodations. Short holiday getaways (one to three nights) in entire homes will also be restricted, and guests booking entire homes will be required to agree to a "mandatory anti-party attestation." "If a booking is identified as higher risk, the guest will either be blocked from booking, or redirected to alternative accommodations on the platform," the company said.Guests will also be required to accept mandatory anti-party attestation. "Guests who can make reservations will need to confirm that they understand that disruptive and unauthorized parties are not allowed on Airbnb, and they face suspension or removal from the platform if they violate this policy," said the company.Airbnb also has a 'Neighborhood Support Line' for local communities to report urgent issues, like a party in progress, at a home they believe is listed on Airbnb.Airbnb's efforts to curb disruptive parties started in 2019 with a ban on "party houses," followed by stricter measures in 2020 due to the pandemic. In 2022, the company permanently banned large parties worldwide following several violent incidents at Airbnb rentals, including a shooting in Pittsburgh that resulted in two deaths and eight injuries.
Article Summary: Airbnb is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. The technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location.

The debate over TikTok‚Äôs presence in the United States has escalated to new heights, as U.S. lawmakers and regulatory bodies intensify efforts to address national security concerns linked to the Chinese-owned app. With 170 million American users, TikTok‚Äôs widespread influence has raised alarms regarding potential data privacy risks and its ties to the Chinese Communist Party (CCP). Following a recent U.S. federal appeals court decision requiring ByteDance, TikTok's parent company, to divest its operations in the U.S. or face a nationwide ban, pressure is mounting on tech giants Apple and Google to remove the app from their platforms by January 19, 2025. This comprehensive article examines the legislative developments, stakeholder responses, and the implications for TikTok and its users.On Friday, Representatives John Moolenaar, a Republican and chair of the House committee on China, and Raja Krishnamoorthi, the top Democrat on the same committee, issued a strong warning to ByteDance and TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew. In their statement, the lawmakers emphasized the urgency of executing a ‚Äúqualified divestiture‚Äù to mitigate risks to U.S. national security and safeguard the app's millions of American users.‚ÄúCongress has acted decisively to defend the national security of the United States and protect TikTok‚Äôs American users from the Chinese Communist Party,‚Äù the lawmakers asserted in a joint letter.ByteDance and TikTok have been under intense scrutiny for their alleged vulnerability to Chinese government influence, which critics argue could enable the CCP to access sensitive user data or manipulate content.Alphabet, the parent company of Google, and Apple, two of the world‚Äôs largest technology firms, have been drawn into the controversy. Lawmakers have instructed the companies to prepare for TikTok‚Äôs removal from their app stores by the January 19 deadline unless ByteDance complies with the divestiture requirement.While neither Apple nor Alphabet has commented on the matter, compliance with such an order would mark a significant moment in the ongoing struggle between the U.S. government and foreign-owned digital platforms.In response to the court ruling, ByteDance and TikTok filed an emergency appeal with the U.S. Supreme Court, seeking to temporarily block the divestiture law while awaiting further judicial review. TikTok has argued that the legislation poses an existential threat to its operations in the U.S., warning that removing the app from mobile platforms would render it unusable for millions of Americans.‚ÄúThe law, absent a court order, means TikTok will disappear from mobile app stores on Jan. 19 and be unavailable to the half of the country that does not already use the app,‚Äù TikTok stated.The app also emphasized that a loss of support services would ‚Äúcripple the platform in the United States,‚Äù effectively dismantling its functionality over time.The core issue driving these developments is TikTok's ownership by ByteDance, a China-based company subject to Chinese data security laws. Critics argue these laws compel companies to cooperate with the Chinese government, raising fears that user data from TikTok could be accessed or exploited by Beijing.Republican Senator Josh Hawley underscored these concerns, stating, ‚ÄúThe main issue is it's subject to Chinese oversight, Beijing oversight ‚Äî that's the problem.‚ÄùLawmakers and national security experts have repeatedly warned that TikTok‚Äôs vast repository of user data, combined with its sophisticated algorithmic capabilities, could pose a significant threat to U.S. interests.If the law takes effect on January 19 without intervention, TikTok will be removed from Apple‚Äôs App Store and Google Play. While the Department of Justice has clarified that this would not directly prohibit current users from continuing to use the app, the lack of ongoing support and updates would eventually render TikTok obsolete in the U.S.For the 170 million Americans who use TikTok, the app‚Äôs removal would represent a dramatic shift in their digital landscape. Creators and businesses that rely on the platform for income and engagement may face significant disruptions.Adding another layer of complexity, President-elect Donald Trump has promised to intervene to prevent a TikTok ban , signaling potential political resistance to the divestiture law. While details of Trump‚Äôs plan remain unclear, his involvement could influence the outcome of the ongoing legal and legislative processes.

He recognizes Google's current advantages, particularly its extensive distribution network on mobile and default placements on Apple and Android devices.In a notable aside, Nadella revealed his long-standing interest in securing an Apple search deal, expressing satisfaction that OpenAI ultimately obtained the partnership. "I've been trying to get an Apple search deal for like 10 years," he said, "and so when Tim finally did a deal with Sam, I was the most thrilled person."The Microsoft CEO remains pragmatic about the competitive AI landscape, describing it as "very competitive" but not a "winner take all" scenario, suggesting Microsoft is far from conceding its position in the rapidly evolving digital ecosystem.

Article Title: Why two of the world‚Äôs biggest chip companies are ‚Äòfighting‚Äô in the US
Article Text:
What is the case all about

What each party is saying

What is at stake

A legal battle between chip giants Arm and Qualcomm is set to begin in a Delaware court . Qualcomm, no stranger to intellectual property disputes, has argued that Arm is using this lawsuit to leverage higher royalty rates and interfere with its product roadmap.Rather than seeking monetary damages, Arm is asking the court to order Qualcomm to destroy products found to infringe on its intellectual property. Arm has even threatened to terminate Qualcomm's license entirely, a move that could have significant consequences for both companies.This trial comes at a critical time for both Arm and Qualcomm, as they seek to expand their reach in new markets, particularly in the booming field of artificial intelligence (AI).Notably, Nuvia was co-founded by former top Apple chip designer Gerard Williams, who is now employed as a senior engineer at Qualcomm. Article Title: Instagram, Facebook, Google, TikTok and other social media platforms have a ‚ÄòMarch 16, 2025 deadline‚Äô
Article Text:
What are Online Safety Act

Hefty fines and potential service disruptions

The UK‚Äôs landmark Online Safety Act officially is now in effect, enabling stricter online content moderation and accountability for tech giants like Meta-owned Facebook and Instagram, Google and TikTok, and others. The legislation empowers Ofcom , the UK's media regulator, to enforce stricter rules on how these companies handle harmful and illegal content on their platforms.The Online Safety Act, passed last year, aims to create a safer online environment, particularly for children. Ofcom has published its first set of codes of practice, outlining the steps tech firms must take to address illegal harms such as terrorism, hate speech, fraud and child sexual abuse.Under the Online Safety Act, tech companies have a ‚Äòduty of care‚Äô to protect users from harmful content. They have three months ‚Äì until March 16, 2025 ‚Äì to assess the risks associated with illegal content on their platforms and implement measures to mitigate those risks.This includes improving content moderation, simplifying reporting mechanisms, and incorporating built-in safety features.‚ÄúThis is a significant step change in online safety. We will be closely monitoring the industry to ensure compliance with these strict safety standards," said Ofcom Chief Executive Melanie Dawes.Companies that will be found in breach of the rules may face substantial fines of up to 10% of their global annual revenue. In cases of repeated or serious violations, senior managers may face jail time, and Ofcom can even seek court orders to block access to non-compliant services in the UK.The new codes mandate that reporting and complaint functions be easily accessible and require high-risk platforms to utilize hash-matching technology to identify and remove child sexual abuse material.Ofcom said that further regulations expected in 2025, including measures to block accounts sharing child sexual abuse material and the use of AI to combat illegal content."These codes bridge the gap between the laws that protect us offline and online. Platforms must step up, or Ofcom has my full support to use its powers, including fines and website blocking," said Technology Minister Peter Kyle.
Article Summary: The UK's landmark Online Safety Act officially is now in effect. The legislation empowers Ofcom to enforce stricter rules on how these companies handle harmful and illegal content. Ofcom has published its first set of codes of practice, outlining the steps tech firms must take to address illegal harms.

Article Title: Why YouTube creators must be careful of brand promotion requests
Article Text:
How hackers target content creators

At a time when people are increasingly choosing YouTube content creation as their profession, hackers have found another way of distributing malware. According to a report, cybercriminals are now targeting YouTube creators via phishing campaigns to get hold of sensitive information.Hackers distribute emails by faking brand collaboration offers to distribute malware, a report by CloudSEK said.The attackers impersonate popular brands, enticing creators with lucrative partnership proposals to trick them into downloading malicious attachments. The malware is disguised as legitimate documents like contracts or promotional materials, and is delivered through password-protected files hosted on platforms such as OneDrive to evade detection.To make emails look legitimate, details like compensation structures based on subscriber count and instructions to access a password-protected zip file containing the supposed agreement and promotional materials are included.However, these seemingly legitimate files contain a hidden danger.‚ÄúOnce downloaded, the malware can steal sensitive information, including login credentials and financial data, while also granting attackers remote access to the victim‚Äôs systems,‚Äù said security researcher Mayank Sahariya.The malware payload is hidden within attachments such as Word documents, PDFs, or Excel files, often masquerading as promotional materials, contracts or business proposals.Since the phishing emails are sent from spoofed or compromised email addresses, it makes them seem credible and recipients are lured into downloading the attached files.‚ÄúWith content creators and marketers as primary targets, this global campaign underscores the importance of verifying collaboration requests and adopting robust cybersecurity measures to protect against such threats,‚Äù he added.When an attachment is opened, the malware installs on the victim's system to steal sensitive data, including login credentials, financial information and intellectual property, or to provide remote access to the attacker.
Article Summary: Hackers are targeting YouTube creators via phishing campaigns to get hold of sensitive information. The attackers impersonate popular brands, enticing creators with lucrative partnership proposals. The malware is disguised as legitimate documents like contracts or promotional materials, and is delivered through password-protected files hosted on platforms such as OneDrive.

Article Title: Credit card scam busted: How the gang stole money from over 50 credit card users through 'phone calls'
Article Text:
Representative Image

Noida Police arrested a gang of six for defrauding over 50 people by falsely promising to increase their credit card limits. Noida Additional Deputy Commissioner of Police (ADCP) Manish Mishra explained that the gang contacted credit card holders by phone, posing as bank officials and offering to raise their credit limits. They used personal information previously obtained to convince victims of their legitimacy. The scammers sent phishing links that directed victims to fake websites mimicking real bank portals.Victims were then instructed to download an app from these fraudulent sites. The app prompted them to enter sensitive data, including credit card details, email addresses, PAN and Aadhar card numbers, current credit limits, expiry dates, and CVV numbers."Using this stolen information and OTPs, the gang purchased expensive items like mobile phones and gold and silver coins from e-commerce sites using the victims' credit cards," ADCP Mishra stated.Following a tip, police arrested Amit Kumar (28), Ravi Kanta (45), Tej Singh (24), Vikash Jha (27), Nagendra Sharma (24), and Nawab Khan (24). The individual responsible for creating the fake website, known as "Mota Bhai," remains at large.The arrested individuals face charges under the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) sections 318(4) (cheating), 336(3) (forgery for cheating), 339 (possession of forged documents), and 340(2) (using forged documents), as well as relevant sections of the IT Act. They have been remanded to judicial custody.
Article Summary: Noida Police arrested a gang of six for defrauding over 50 people by falsely promising to increase their credit card limits. The gang contacted credit card holders by phone, posing as bank officials and offering to raise their credit limits. They used personal information previously obtained to convince victims of their legitimacy.
